title: 114_hr3721
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Affordable College Textbook Act". The high cost of college textbooks is a barrier for many students in achieving higher education. The average student budget for college books and supplies at 4-year public institutions was $1,225 during the 2014-2015 academic year. New textbook prices increased 82 percent between 2002 and 2012, and more efforts are needed to address rising costs. The Internet has enabled the creation and sharing of digital content, including open educational resources. Using open educational resources in large college courses can reduce textbook costs by 80 to 100 percent. Federal investment in expanding open educational resources could significantly lower college textbook costs and reduce financial barriers to higher education. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, definitions include terms like "educational resource" for materials used in postsecondary instruction, "institution of higher education" as defined in the Higher Education Act of 1965, "open educational resource" for freely available educational materials, and "open textbook" as an open educational resource. An open educational resource, whether a textbook or alternative material for postsecondary courses, can be used at institutions of higher education. "Relevant faculty" includes both tenure track and contingent members involved in creating or using these resources. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Education. The grant program is established. The Secretary will provide grants to eligible higher education institutions for pilot programs expanding the use of open textbooks to save students money. Eligible entities must submit applications detailing the project to be funded. The eligible entity must submit a plan for promoting open textbooks, evaluating existing resources, quality review, and disseminating project results to other institutions. The eligible entity must submit a plan for promoting open textbooks, evaluating existing resources, quality review, and disseminating project results to other institutions. Special consideration will be given to applications that demonstrate potential for high student savings, expanded use of open textbooks in postsecondary courses, and collaboration with relevant faculty in the development of the application. An eligible entity receiving a grant must produce high-quality open textbooks that are easily utilized and adapted by faculty members, correspond to high enrollment courses, and are created or adapted in partnership with entities for marketing and distribution. Grant funds can be used for professional development for faculty and staff. The grant funds can be used for professional development, creation or adaptation of open educational resources, development of tools supporting open textbooks, research on the efficacy of open textbooks, and partnerships with other entities for these activities. Educational resources created must be licensed under a non-exclusive, permanent license. The educational resources created or adapted under this section shall be licensed under a non-exclusive, permanent license for public use, with attribution required. The digital content must be freely accessible on a designated website in a downloadable, editable, and redistributable format. Upon completion of a project, an eligible entity must submit a report to the Secretary on the effectiveness of the pilot program. The pilot program aims to expand the use of open textbooks, achieve savings for students, impact higher education institutions, create educational resources under a grant, and report project costs. Appropriations are authorized for five fiscal years. SEC. 5. PRICE INFORMATION.

Amends Section 133(b) of the Higher Education Act of 1965 to update requirements for college textbooks, including printed materials, computer disks, website access, and electronically distributed materials.

SEC. 6. SENSE OF CONGRESS.

Congress encourages higher education institutions to consider open textbooks within academic freedom principles for faculty to choose appropriate course materials.

SEC. 7. REPORT TO CONGRESS. SEC. 7. REPORT TO CONGRESS. The Secretary will submit a report to Congress within 2 years of this Act detailing open textbooks created, adoption rates, and savings generated. SEC. 8. GAO REPORT. The Comptroller General will submit a report to Congress within 3 years of this Act on the cost of textbooks in higher education, focusing on cost changes, contributing factors, use of open textbooks, and their impact on costs.
